ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: As an opportunity to apply the policy sciences framework to a specific case study, I found this course incredibly valuable and transformative. Also, there are no questions here asking for a review of the TF, Lily Sweikert, but I would like to take the time to express how fundamentally important she was to the course. She kept everything running smoothly and helped keep everyone organized during the field trip. She put in many, many more hours of work than she was compensated for, and our class benefitted immensely from her presence.

Question 1: readings were entirely written by the professor or students of the professor. I think this was very biased and the readings were focused primarily on the policy sciences or interdisciplinarity/integration. Very few of the readings were focused on the actual course topic of large-scale conservation. In the future, I would like to have more variety of authors that actually address large-scale conservation issues, or alternatively, the course should be advertised for what it is - a course about policy sciences.Question 2: out of class assignments varied from being very helpful to unhelpful and time consuming. The appraisal paper and the presentation were most helpful, while assignments like short reflection papers were not useful. Unsure if the professor actually read any of the work handed in since we did not receive feedback outside of in class time
The field trips were the highlights of this course
There was a field trip to Jackson Hole, but I was not able to attend. Perhaps I would have found the class more beneficial if I'd been able to go on the field trip.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trip. This was an on-the-ground opportunity to explore conservation in a totally different light. I would say that the field trip was the most important part of the course.
Field trip.

THe field trip was the best opportunity that I've had at FES to reconnect with the real world and understand how practitioners actually deal with complex conservation problems on the ground.Susan's commitment to her students is also unparalleled at FES. Of all the courses I've taken at this school, the insights gained through working with her have been some of the most valuable.
The field trip was very helpful and I learned the most from this trip
The field trip and being able to bind together our stay in FES

The premise of the course â navigating the decision-making process and social context of implementing Large-Scale Conservation â is fascinating, and carries the course through some slow individual sessions.
The classroom discussions were a highlight in this class, and the various visitors that Susan introduced brought diverse perspectives and feedback especially during student presentations.
The best aspects of the course was the opportunity to "ground truth" and apply an integrative policy sciences framework to a real world conservation problem.
The atmosphere of the class, the discussion and the guests who occasionally attended.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The lectures weren't always clear.
Field trip to Yellowstone.
The TA should not have been a first year. While she was critical to organizing the course material on a weekly basis, she also treated the students in the class like children.
See above comments
I think the instructor could be more receptive to student commentary.

Accountability. While there is definitely something to be said for treating students as equals and as all adults, student life is incredibly hectic and busy, and if there is no hard deadline or if we know we won't be held accountable to the readings, then they become not the top priority. I think increasing accountability to readings and discussions would help the content of the course.Also, the vast amount of literature was by Susan Clark herself, which meant that we didn't see other perspectives or a critique of the recommended process. What are the limitations and pitfalls of this approach?

I would ensure that all students are well grounded in the policy sciences theoretical framework to allow more robust conversations, in addition to having more structured ways to reflect and embed learning.
The assignments. We need more!

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There was no lab section.
Yes. More discussion. More participation.
I think the class would benefit from more distinct lectures and case studies. Often, it can be hard to know exactly what we're talking about.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course is important for my overall program, as it taught me how to perform policy sciences analysis in situ.
Great. We learn more about interdisciplinary study.
Good expansion on the policy process and learning how to view complex policy problems with a holistic lens.
The course brings me back to reality and link academic work with real life situation.

This is the capstone course of my program and is the course I have been waiting for my entire degree to take. It integrates many of the somewhat disparate threads that I have learned in other classes into a more coherent and applied body of knowledge.
It allowed me to explore my research site in a new and interesting way. I appreciated the obvious investment by the instructor and the fresh perspective the class provided my same research.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To have the chance to apply the policy sciences in situ and examine conservation in a different way than I had previously.
Interest.
To gain skills in identifying and analyzing social and policy processes that are part of environmental problems.
Because Susan is fantastic, and I wanted to become more adept at using the policy process framework.
I really like the work professor Susan was doing and had to know her. She has a lot to offer.
I thought the topic sounded fascinating; and I needed a capstone.
I took this course to refine and hone my skills in the policy sciences and see the opportunities and challenges to applying it on the ground.
For the reason written in question 17.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes - they exceeded my expectation.
Yes.
Yes.
Exceeded expectations
Learned about the policy sciences framework but little about large-scale conservation efforts outside of in Yellowstone
Yes it very much did.
Yes, more or less.
I was hoping to have a clearer understanding of the policy framework, but I still feel that it is a vague concept that I can't really be put to practice.
Yes. The skills and knowledge I learned in this class far exceeded my expectations and I believe that I will draw on these perspectives and ideas for the rest of my life.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The advantage of group work was getting to bounce ideas off one another and explore topics. I didn't feel there were any disadvantages to group work in this course.
Great.
Work group was good and I learned a lot
It helped us interact and an learn about different standpoints.
My partner helped share the burden; and contributed ideas that I would not have thought of on my own.
The group work really helped students develop a shared understanding of the policy sciences.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it! Lots of material to cover, particularly for those students who did not Susan's Foundations course, but a very valuable class.
Take the field trip.
Anybody and everybody should take this course. I believe everybody in FES need this course to bring one back to reality...
Make sure you go on the fieldtrip â I wasn't able to, and my course experience suffered as a result.
Take this course. It will provide you with a framework to integrate knowledge that other courses don't provide and that will serve you for the remainder of your professional and personal life.
Make sure the issues and the framework is one you want to go deep with, because its immensely useful, but you have to be ready to go there.
